content.title: Asthma Exacerbation (Acute Asthma Attack)
content.summary: Acute worsening of asthma symptoms requiring urgent treatment
key_points: Recognize severity: mild, moderate, severe, life-threatening
IV magnesium for severe refractory cases
Discharge with ICS or step-up therapy; asthma action plan

statement.text: Asthma exacerbation is a progressive increase in dyspnea, cough, wheezing, or chest tightness requiring urgent treatment. Management involves repeated inhaled short-acting bronchodilators, early systemic corticosteroids, and assessment for escalation including ipratropium, magnesium sulfate, and rarely intubation.
statement.formal: Asthma Exacerbation Rx = SABA q20min × 3 + Systemic steroids + (severe: add ipratropium ± IV MgSO4) + O2 to SpO2 93-95%

explanation.intuition: An asthma attack is the airways suddenly clamping down, swelling, and filling with mucus all at once. Treatment works to rapidly reverse the bronchospasm (SABA), reduce inflammation (steroids), and buy time for the airways to open up.
explanation.key_insight: Systemic steroids take 4-6 hours to work - give them early. SABA provides immediate relief. The combination is synergistic. Never rely on bronchodilators alone without addressing inflammation.

definitions_glossary.asthma_exacerbation: Acute worsening requiring urgent treatment escalation
definitions_glossary.status_asthmaticus: Severe persistent asthma not responding to standard treatment
definitions_glossary.systemic_steroids: Oral or IV corticosteroids to reduce airway inflammation
definitions_glossary.ipratropium: Anticholinergic bronchodilator for additive effect in severe cases
definitions_glossary.magnesium_sulfate: IV vasodilator and bronchodilator for refractory severe asthma
definitions_glossary.peak_expiratory_flow: PEF - simple objective measure of airflow obstruction
definitions_glossary.accessory_muscle_use: Visible SCM, intercostal retractions indicating severe work of breathing
definitions_glossary.pulsus_paradoxus: SBP drop >10mmHg with inspiration; indicates severe obstruction
definitions_glossary.silent_chest: Absence of wheezing in severe asthma - ominous sign of minimal air movement
definitions_glossary.intubation_in_asthma: Last resort; avoid with aggressive medical management

pathophysiology.mechanism: Trigger → mast cell degranulation → bronchoconstriction + mucus hypersecretion + airway edema → severe airflow limitation → V/Q mismatch → hypoxemia; if prolonged → respiratory muscle fatigue → hypercapnia

SABA.albuterol: MDI 4-8 puffs q20min × 3, then q1-4h; or continuous neb 10-15mg/h
SABA.delivery: MDI with spacer as effective as nebulizer

ipratropium.indication: Add to SABA for severe exacerbations

systemic_steroids.dose: Prednisone 40-60mg PO or IV methylprednisolone equivalent
systemic_steroids.duration: 5-7 days; no taper needed for short courses
systemic_steroids.timing: Give within first hour - delays lead to more admissions

magnesium_sulfate.indication: Severe exacerbation not responding to initial therapy

heliox.mechanism: Lower density gas improves flow in obstructed airways

treatment_options.oxygen: Target SpO2 93-95% (adults); avoid hyperoxia in severe

intubation.technique: RSI with ketamine (bronchodilator properties), anticipate difficult ventilation

definition.@value: Acute worsening of asthma symptoms requiring urgent escalation of treatment including bronchodilators and systemic steroids

medicalCode.description: Mild intermittent asthma with acute exacerbation

learning_objectives: Recognize signs of impending respiratory failure
clinical_pearls: Give steroids within 1 hour - delays increase admissions
MDI + spacer is as effective as nebulizer for most patients
Silent chest = ominous sign (no air movement to generate wheeze)
IV MgSO4 for severe refractory cases - safe and effective
After discharge: step up controller therapy, provide action plan
